column1: Armadale is a suburb of Perth within the City of Armadale
column2: located on the south-eastern edge of the Perth metropolitan region. The major junction of the South Western and Albany Highways
column3: which connect Perth with the South West and Great Southern regions of Western Australia respectively
column4: is located within the suburb. It is also the terminus of the Armadale railway line
column5: one of five major railway lines to service Perth.

column2: the area now known as Armadale was long occupied by Aboriginal people prior to the founding of the Swan River Colony. Records of encounters with the original Aboriginal inhabitants of this district are sparse in detail
column3: but early on there was conflict between these inhabitants and the settlers
column4: which led to the establishment of a small garrison at Kelmscott.  The township of Kelmscott was gazetted in 1830
column5: and for the next sixty years was the administrative and social hub for those colonists who took up land between present-day Kelmscott and Byford.

column1: Interest in settlement at Kelmscott waned soon after the township was established
column2: the district's inaccessibility (no road from Perth having yet been formed) and a general shortage of labour being factors mitigating against farming in that area. However
column3: several large land grants had been taken up in the district
column4: including one of over 8000 acres (Location 31) initially held by John Adams
column5: and over the next few decades this allocated land presented a constraint to others seeking land for settlement in the area.  Parts of these larger allocations were subdivided and on-sold
column6: and smaller allocations were taken up alongside them. Thus
column7: during the 1840s a number of farming properties were established in the foothills along the Canning River
column9: Wongong Brook and Beenyup Brook. Names of these early settlers included White
column13: and Mead.In late 1846 the Swan River Colony's first mine was established in the area now known as Armadale. The mine was the first undertaking of the Western Australian Mining Company
column15: and the object was to extract lead or copper - the ores of both metals having been in evidence. Land was purchased
column16: and over the next few years shafts were dug by contractors.  There was little yield
column17: and in 1850 shareholders resolved to wind up the operation. One of the shafts of this mining venture is still extant south of Bedfordale Hill Road.By 1835
column18: a road had been surveyed from Perth to Kelmscott and within a few years roads to Albany and Bunbury were also marked out enabling the establishment of overland mail services. However
column19: it was not until 1851 that work began to properly form the road between Perth and Kelmscott.  The work was assisted by the arrival of convict labour in 1852
column20: and during the next few years the roads from Kelmscott to Albany and from Kelmscott to Pinjarra were formed. It was at the junction of the roads to Albany and Pinjarra that the township of Armadale was born when an enterprising settler saw opportunity to establish a wayside inn there
column21: some time around 1853. The property was sold to Thomas Saw in 1856
column24: in 1856 he applied for a wayside licence to sell liquor. Their wayside inn was named the Neerigin Inn after the brook that flowed out of the Darling Range at this point.  For many years the district was known as Neerigin or Narrogin
column25: and a hotel bearing this name still stands on the site of the original wayside inn.In 1889
column26: the northern section of the South Western Railway was constructed from Perth to what is now Armadale
column27: and in 1897 a station was built at this location to service the sparsely scattered population of this district. It has been claimed that the station was named 'Armadale' because a name other than Neerigin had to be found to avoid confusion with the wheatbelt town of Narrogin
column28: and that from this the town which sprung up near the station took its name. Other theories have also been put forward for the origin of the name. What is certain is that the name was not in use before the arrival of the railway.The railway provided impetus for growth in the district
column29: and in May 1893 local residents held a public meeting to discuss the creation of a roads board that could give attention to the maintenance and development of local roads.  At this point in time
column30: roads in the district were the responsibility of the Canning
column33: Murray and Wandering road boards for all of whom it was an outlying and unimportant area. In October 1894
column34: Parliament agreed to the formation of a roads board which on 12 December 1894 was gazetted as the 'Kelmscott Roads Board'
column35: later to be the Armadale-Kelmscott Roads Board (1910)
column38: and now the City of Armadale (1985).

column1: St Matthews Anglican Church (1904) and old manse.  Designed by prominent architect Sir Joseph John Talbot Hobbs (1864-1938)

South Western Highway.  Located just above the Narrogin Inn

column2: being an urban centre and transport hub for the surrounding districts
column3: contains a variety of educational institutions. It is home to two state high schools
column4: four state primary schools
column5: three independent schools (one of which extends to year 12)
column6: an Australian Trades College campus and a campus of South Metropolitan TAFE (formerly Polytechnic West).

column2: Armadale State School was established in the Mechanics Institute Hall which was located on the present-day carpark of the Armadale Town Hall. A purpose-built school building was erected at the intersection of Church and Third Roads in 1900.  This was initially a single classroom
column3: but by 1905 a second classroom was added. The district's population increased steadily in the first half of the 20th Century
column4: and additional classrooms were added to the school as the need presented.  A Roman Catholic School
column5: St Francis Xavier
column6: was established uphill on Third Road in 1938.  This school has recently relocated to Forrest Road
column8: the population growth was more rapid and the State saw fit to establish a regional high school in Armadale. Armadale Senior High School opened in 1955
column9: initially only as a high school but from 1963 it catered for years 11 and 12).From 1951
column10: a community of Dutch migrants who were members of the Free Reformed Church settled in the district and they opened a parent run school on Robinhood Avenue in December 1957.  Originally catering for years 1 to 6 and known as John Calvin School (now John Calvin Christian College)
column11: the campus evolved to incorporate a junior high school
column13: and more recently the primary school functions have relocated to the campuses established at Kelmscott and Byford.

column2: new State-run primary schools opened: Kingsley (1969)
column3: Neerigen Brook (1970)
column4: Challis (1974)
column5: and Gwynne Park (1978). In 1983
column6: the Pioneer Village School and Dale Christian School opened
column7: the latter having relocated to the site of the former Drive-In Cinema in Brookdale. Other State and private schools have been established in neighbouring population centres of Westfield
column9: Roleystone and Byford.  Other high schools were opened at Kelmscott in the 1970s
column10: West Armadale (Cecil Andrews High School) in 1980
column11: and Roleystone in 1983. Cecil Andrews College is the base of the Australian Air Force Cadets Number 719 Squadron.

column2: Armadale Primary School relocated to a new campus on Carradine Road
column3: its current location
column4: and the original school site was cleared to make way for an expansion of Armadale Shopping City.  In recognition of its heritage value
column5: the 1899 school building was relocated to Minnawarra Park
column6: its walls and roof lifted and carried to the new site intact
column7: the first known case of a substantial brick structure relocation project undertaken in Australia.  The Old Jarrah Tree which used to be in the playground near the 1905 classroom is the only in situ remains at the school's original site. A collection of artefacts recovered from beneath the earliest parts of the school during the move are held by History House Museum and provide tangible insights into school life at Armadale during the early 1900s.

column2: a TAFE Centre was built in Commerce Avenue as part of the South-East Metropolitan College of TAFE; it became a fully functioning campus in 2003 when SEMC merged into Swan TAFE
column3: then become a campus of Polytechnic West and in 2016 merged with Challenger Institute of Technology to become South Metropolitan TAFE. In 2010

column5: cabinet making and electrical trades.

column1: The intersection of four key roads is located at the centre of Armadale:
Armadale Road (State Route 14) – west to Cockburn Central and Fremantle;
Albany Highway (State Route 30) – north to Cannington and Perth;
Albany Highway (State Route 30) – east to Albany;
South Western Highway (State Route 20) – south to Pinjarra and Bunbury.
Armadale is the terminus of the Armadale railway line
column2: which links the suburb to Perth's central business district and the suburban centres of Cannington
column3: Maddington and Gosnells. Its railway station serves as an interchange for Transperth buses
column4: operated by sWAn Transit
column5: which serve surrounding areas
column6: as well as a stop on the Australind train to Bunbury.

column1: Bus routes 243–245 serve western Armadale and Cecil Andrews SHS
column2: whilst 250 serves the southwest
column5: 253 and 254 serves the growing area of Byford with 252 services terminating at Mundijong plus the 253 at Jarrahdale and 220 and 249 service Albany Highway. The 519 travels between Armadale and Murdoch. There are no bus routes servicing eastern Armadale.

column2: Joseph Bolitho
column3: aka Moondyne Joe (c. 1826–1900); one of Western Australia's best known bushrangers who hid out in the hills above Armadale-Kelmscott.

column2: Thomas (1826–1918); founder of the Neerigin Inn and entrepreneur whose family were leaders in the civic and economic development of the district.  Thomas Saw arrived in the Swan River Colony in 1848
column3: settling in Claisebrook from where he worked as a carpenter and joiner.

column1: Sir Emile Algernon Arthur Keppel Cowell-Stepney
column2: 2nd Baronet (1834–1909)
column3: British aristocrat
column4: landowner and politician. In 1896 he became part owner of the vineyard established at Armadale a few years prior
column5: and from 1899 he became the sole owner of this vineyard which he renamed 'Derry NaSura'.  Sir Arthur was known for his philanthropic support of Mechanics Institutes (an early form of public library).

column2: William Lambden (1861–1946); engineer and public servant involved in mining and the development of infrastructure (including railways and lighthouses) in various parts of Western Australia
column3: some time warden of the goldfields (a title he retained)
column4: Resident Magistrate
column5: and gentleman farmer in early Armadale. He was the donor of the land on which the Mechanics Institute was built in 1895 which later became the site of the Armadale Town Hall.  While living in Armadale
column6: Owen wrote Cossack gold: the chronicles of an early goldfields warden (1933
column7: reprinted 1984). An engineering scholarship in the name of William Lambden Owen is annually offered by the University of Western Australia
column8: having been established by Owen's niece
column9: the late Miss Edith Stewart Gordon.

column2: Martin Edward (1862–1917); public servant
column3: gentleman farmer and initiator of the subdivision that gave form to the core of the Armadale township.  The main street is named after Mr and Mrs (Dr) Jull.

column2: Dr Henrietta Margaritta (1872–1961); medical professional and social reformer
column3: mother of Drake-Brockman
column4: Henrietta Frances (1901–1968)

column2: Ivor Treharne (1892–1976); journalist
column3: Roleystone resident and shire councillor
column4: and a founder of the local History House Museum.  The local studies library is named after him.

column2: Sir Fred Joyce (1900–1969); educator
column3: former principal of the Armadale Primary School
column4: vice-chancellor of the University of Queensland from 1960 to 1969 (where a road and buildings still bear the names of Sir Fred and his wife
column5: a fellow educator of note)
column6: and author or co-author of numerous other spelling and diction books that have been staples for primary education reading in Australia from the 1930s to the present time.  Sir Fred's best known publication is The Schonell Speller (1932). The readers that he co-authored for early primary students
column7: featuring the characters Dick and Dora and their pets Nip and Fluff
column8: were familiar to generations of schoolchildren in English-speaking countries (but not America). Sir Fred held numerous voluntary posts. In 1962 he was granted a knighthood.

column2: Vincent Noel AM (1916–2007); naturalist who was born at and spent part of his childhood in Armadale.
Janet AC (born 1943).  Widow of Robert Holmes à Court (d.1990)

column2: Rodney William (born 1947); cricketer

column2: Ben (born 1978); a former Australian rules footballer and Brownlow medallist
